35.text:
This is a response to creationmuseum’s video,
“Bill Nye, Creationism is Highly Appropriate

40.text:
for Our Children”.
Well, as promised, it’s time to roll up

44.text:
my sleeves and get down to dealing with the
intellectual powerhouses of the creationist

48.text:
cesspool known as Answers in Genesis, and
more specifically with what they had to say

52.text:
about Bill Nye and his Big Think video.
But before we begin, I think we should frame

57.text:
this video with a little context. You see,
on his AiG blog, Mr. Ham proudly announced

63.text:
the excretion of this videographic offering
by introducing his marionettes as follows,

68.text:
and I quote: ‘These two PhD scientists were
asked to reply to Mr. Nye, whose academic

74.text:
credentials do not come close to Drs. Menton
and Purdom.’

78.text:
Well, this was indeed a bold claim by the
shit-flinger-in chief, and since he’s quite

83.text:
used to people unwisely taking his word for
all manner of preposterous propositions I’m

88.text:
sure that he expected everyone reading his
blog to do the same. Well, unfortunately for

93.text:
him, I don’t operate that way so I thought
it would be best to investigate the backgrounds

97.text:
of these two scientific colossi to make everyone
fully aware of who we’re dealing with, and

102.text:
exactly how qualified they are to claim that
they know better than the most brilliant minds

107.text:
in science both past and present.
As you’ll shortly discover, my investigation

112.text:
led to me forming an opinion of these two
individuals that’s somewhat less than favorable,

116.text:
since they’ve apparently been more enthusiastic
about spending their lives shitting all over

121.text:
science instead of promoting or doing it.
As a result I’m afraid that referring to

126.text:
them as “Dr.” may lead to me choking on
my own words, and since I can’t rely on

131.text:
any of my viewers knowing the Heimlich Maneuver
I’ll instead be using some more appropriate

135.text:
sobriquets for them.
We’ll begin with Georgia Purdom, nee Hickman,

140.text:
aka Tweedle-dum. Ms. Dum received a PhD in
Molecular Genetics from Ohio State in 2000,

147.text:
and a quick search through the literature
reveals that she’s published a grand total

150.text:
of three peer-reviewed papers, none of which,
interestingly, appear from her tenure as a

156.text:
‘scientist’ at AiG. And while this might
en face seem abnormally respectable for a

162.text:
creationist, unfortunately for Ms. Dum, her
contributions apparently only merited third-place

167.text:
authorship on all three publications.
Since established convention dictates that,

172.text:
other than the principal investigator who’s
name appears last, authors are ranked in order

176.text:
of their relative contributions, coming out
of a PhD with only third-authorships really

181.text:
is a quite pitiful showing and tantamount
to nothing short of – and I apologize for

187.text:
using technical terms here –a dismal and
unmitigated fucking failure.

194.text:
And then we have David Menton, aka Tweedle-Dee.
Now at the onset I’ll admit that his record

200.text:
is substantially superior to Ms. Dum’s abysmal
qualifications and, in fact, a cursory glance

205.text:
at his bio on the AiG webshite might even
convince the casual observer that it’s impressive.

211.text:
Mr. Dee received his PhD from Brown, a prestigious
Ivy League institution, followed by a forty-year

217.text:
career, thirty-four of which were at Washington
University in St. Louis.

221.text:
From what I could discover from PubMed and
the Web of Science, over those four decades

225.text:
he produced a grand total of twenty-seven
papers. Now, that might seem impressive to

230.text:
the uninitiated, but let’s back up and put
that into context, shall we? I consider myself

235.text:
at best a middle-of-the-road scientist and
have my name on sixteen papers in the eighteen

239.text:
years since I received my PhD. That’s an
average of 0.89 per year compared to Mr. Dum’s

246.text:
0.68 – but considering that I’ve spent
sixteen of those eighteen years working in

250.text:
industry and so haven’t been able to publish
the majority of my research, while Mr. Dum

255.text:
has spent the bulk of his in a premier research
university where publication is practically

260.text:
compulsory, his contribution begins to shrink
even more and suggests that the only reason

264.text:
he stuck it out there for so long was because
of an unfortunate calamity that occurred during

269.text:
the assignment of tenure, since the record
seems to indicate that he was what bona fide

274.text:
academics affectionately refer to as ‘dead
wood’.

278.text:
In this light it’s interesting to note that
while the AiG webshite proudly provides a

282.text:
link to Mr. Dee’s creationist scribbling,
it doesn’t do the same for his legitimate

287.text:
work, making one wonder whether Mr. Ham also
realizes that Mr. Dee’s “wood” could

292.text:
do with a spot of Viagra.
And if that assessment seems harsh, let’s

296.text:
compare myself and Mr. Dum to a real scientist.
in this case Professor James Rothman at Yale

302.text:
– someone who’s won the Lasker Medal and
is in the running for a Nobel – and who

307.text:
in 40 years has published two hundred and
forty two papers – or over six a year. Furthermore

313.text:
Jim’s citation index, an average of how
often his papers are referenced by others

317.text:
and so a measure of their importance in the
field, is a whopping 165, dwarfing my 76,

324.text:
but by nowhere near as much as Mr. Dum’s
sad and shriveled 25.

329.text:
Now I’m aware that this protracted introduction
may lead to accusations of ad hominem argumentation

335.text:
and of poisoning the well, so I want to make
it clear that my intent isn’t to discredit

340.text:
their arguments and assertions by proxy because
I’ll be dealing with those in turn shortly.

345.text:
Instead, because of Mr. Ham’s use his blog
to imply an argument from authority, I felt

350.text:
it important to point out exactly how qualified
these individuals actually are, since not

355.text:
everyone is aware that not all PhDs are created
equal.

359.text:
So in summary, from my perspective, if someone
of the stature of a Jim Rothman were to come

364.text:
to me and claim that some well-established
area of biology was erroneous, I would at

369.text:
the very least be obliged to take some time
to hear them out. When, on the other hand,

373.text:
the seemingly unending line of pseudo- or
unqualified creationists numbnuts of which

378.text:
the Tweedles are our latest example do the
same, I expect them to either immediately

383.text:
produce empirical evidence and some very strong
arguments, or to fuck right off because their

388.text:
pitiful qualifications mean absolutely jack-shit
to me.

394.text:
“The first point that Bill Nye makes is
that denial of evolution is unique to the

400.text:
United States. I’m sure that he knows better
than that. After all, not only is evolution

406.text:
criticize certainly d widely in the United

evolution is believed to be false in the Muslim
World. Creationism is … er… taught in

418.text:
South Africa, India, South Korea, Brazil.
Err… smaller factions of creationists probably

424.text:
are found in Japan, Israel, Australia, New

429.text:
Aaah – the argumentum ad populum. Nice start,
Dee. While I admit that Bill Nye could have

437.text:
chosen his words more carefully, it should
be quite clear that what he meant was that

441.text:
the United States is the only place in the
developed world where dumbfucks like you are

taken seriously by a substantial number of

450.text:
that you might actually do some significant
harm.

453.text:
And while you did acknowledge that your insanity
is sadly all too prevalent in the U.S., you

457.text:
didn’t mention that your compatriots in
most of these other countries are marginalized

461.text:
by the populace as the delusional loons they
are, presumably because that would hardly

465.text:
add to the impression you tried to create
here by dishonestly trying to overstate the

469.text:
acceptance of your buffoonery world-wide.
Well, Dee, I regret to inform you that the

475.text:
fact that that the world is liberally sprinkled
with the demented fucktards that can be referred

480.text:
to by the catch-all “creationists” doesn’t
validate nor in any way diminish the magnitude

485.text:
of your fucktardation – it merely demonstrates
that you’re not the only cretin on the planet

490.text:
and gives the rest of us yet another reason
to despair at the state of our species.

496.text:
Thus if you want your pronouncements to receive
even a small modicum of respect, you might

501.text:
consider spending some time putting that alleged
science background to use and doing some actual

505.text:
experimental research to back up your bullshit,
rather than resorting to vacuous and fallacious

510.text:
argumentation.
“Bill Nye implies in his video that parents

517.text:
and other adults are doing a great disservice
to children by teaching them about biblical

522.text:
creation. Well, you might be interested to
know that I also teach my young daughter about

526.text:
evolution. And I know many other Christian
parents who do the same.”

530.text:
Well, Dum, as I already told your organ-grinder
in Holy Hallucinations 34, if you think that

538.text:
sane people believe that you and your fellow
intellectual cripples are teaching your children

543.text:
anything other than a deliberately inaccurate
and shoddily constructed straw man of evolutionary

548.text:
theory, then you’ve got another thing coming.
The veracity of my conjecture will be bolstered

553.text:
shortly when I deal with some of your other
comments, but before we move on I thought

557.text:
it would be illuminating to compare what the
reverend Ham said about creationist pedagogy

562.text:
in his first video: “Creationists are teaching
children that they’re special”; with what

566.text:
you said in your interview with Michael Shermer
on his recent visit to the Creation Museum:

571.text:
“All of us have sinned. Even a one-year
old child. I have a five-year-old daughter.

577.text:
She’s a guilty sinner.”
I have to say that this shines as clear a

579.text:
light as I’ve ever seen on the magnitude
of the mental illness that you delusional

584.text:
and deliberately ignorant buffoons are suffering
from. Not only have you managed to convince

590.text:
yourselves that your woefully inadequate brains
are in some way superior to some of the greatest

595.text:
minds of the present and the past, but you’re
also so profoundly stupid that you’re unable

600.text:
to maintain even a scrap of internal consistency
within the childish fantasy that you’ve

605.text:
constructed and are trying to pass off as
a world view. If this is any indication of

611.text:
the kind of education you’re provided for
your daughter… then I feel like crying for

617.text:
her.
“Children should be exposed to both ideas

629.text:
concerning our past. Being a good scientist
and a Mom, I want my daughter to be educated

634.text:
about evolution so that she can see the inherent
problems with it. For example, the complete

639.text:
lack of a genetic mechanism that allows organisms
to gain genetic information to go from simple

644.text:
to complex over time.”
As I’ve already demonstrated, you, madam,

649.text:
are as far away from being a “good” scientist
as I am from winning the “Nicest Knockers

654.text:
on Youtube” award. As for being a good Mom,
well, I have no reason to doubt that you’re

659.text:
doing a fine job tending to her physical well-being,
but as we’ve already seen any claims of

664.text:
you doing the same for her psychological and
educational welfare would be dubious at best.

669.text:
As for your example, I can’t tell you how
many times I’ve heard this particular crock

673.text:
of shit being enthusiastically filled by creationists.
This is generally because, in the supreme

679.text:
confidence born of their seemingly endless
ignorance, they’re completely unaware of,

684.text:
or else just deliberately ignoring the phenomenon
of gene duplication, which has been documented

689.text:
countless times and occurs via mechanisms
as diverse as genome or chromosome duplication,

694.text:
transposition, retrotransposition, unequal
crossover and chromosomal breakage and fusion.

700.text:
And while I might excuse this oversight by
an irredeemable fucktard like Nephilimfree,

705.text:
whose brain appears to have been replaced
by a walnut that was shat out by a choleraic

709.text:
squirrel, you don’t have that luxury because
you hold a PhD in Molecular Genetics – a

715.text:
PhD that now seems as deserved as Ian Juby’s
Mensa membership. This assertion alone not

721.text:
only confirms my suspicions of the kind of
evolutionary “education” you’re providing

726.text:
your daughter with, but proves that you’re
nothing but a vile and loathsome, filthy liar.

732.text:
I know that if I were in a position of power
at Ohio State I’d be doing everything I

736.text:
could to revoke that PhD from you, Ms. Dum,
but since I’m not then the best I can do

741.text:
is to tell you to take your disgusting lie
and shove it up your arsehole until you feel

746.text:
it tickling your tonsils.
“Bill Nye also makes the comment that the

753.text:
world becomes fantastically complicated …er…
if one believes in creation. I would argue

760.text:
that the world becomes fantastically complicated
if one believes in evolution. You see, in

765.text:
evolution you have to look at that hummingbird
feeding at your feeder and assume that all

768.text:
of its parts have somehow come together by
random, purposeless change combined with natural

774.text:
selection, which is nothing more than differential
reproduction.”

779.text:
You can argue all you like, Dee, but that
doesn’t mean that those of us who know better

784.text:
won’t smell your bullshit from half-way
across the internet. You see, despite the

788.text:
equivocation of your version of the word “belief”,
that is – the blind and unquestioning acceptance

793.text:
of propositions in the complete absence of
evidence, or in your case despite over a century

798.text:
of evidence to the contrary – and that used
by people who’s diploma’s aren’t printed

803.text:
on toilet paper – that is the provisional
acceptance of propositions based on empirical

808.text:
and verifiable evidence, I’m afraid that
Mr. Nye made a valid point.

813.text:
The complexity of evolution you describe is
due to the inevitable intricacy of emergent

817.text:
properties resulting from the interaction
of effectively infinite numbers of infinitesimal

821.text:
particles that nevertheless can be understood
using relatively crude, mathematically tractable

826.text:
approximations of their behavior.
And while it could be argued that your perspective

831.text:
is infinitely simpler because you can, and
do, explain everything with an intellectually

835.text:
lazy and vacuous appeal to the magic of a
shaman in the sky, I believe the complexities

840.text:
Mr. Nye was referring to were the psychological
contortions creationists must go through to

844.text:
keep their heads from dislodging from the
comfort of their gluteal resting places. From

850.text:
the bizarre and frankly profoundly retarded
ad hoc explanations you’re forced to continually

854.text:
devise as yet more evidence in support of
evolutionary theory is uncovered; to your

859.text:
almost supernatural ability to ignore said
evidence when it’s all but kicking you repeatedly

863.text:
in the balls to attract your attention; to
having to continually run from here to there

868.text:
like demented simpletons to cover up the cracks
showing up in your ramshackle explanations;

873.text:
to being forced to lie like rabbi caught at
the breakfast bar at Denny’s to cover up

877.text:
the fact that you have no evidence to support
your claims and a world of evidence that’s

882.text:
pounding them up the arse as hard and as fast
as Donald Trump chasing after his hair on

886.text:
a windy day.
And all of this just to deny an elegant, beautifully

891.text:
self-consistent reality that occurs through
observed and observable physical processes

895.text:
in favor of a fantastical and evidently erroneous
alternative that relies on the evocation of

901.text:
supernatural events that have never been observed
by anybody.

904.text:
“We need to understand in the video, that
Bill Nye is confusing observational science

911.text:
with historical science. Observational science
is what I call ‘here and now’ science.

915.text:
It gives us inventions and technology like
computers and vaccines. We can observe it,

920.text:
test it and repeat it. Historical science
deals with the past, and both evolution and

925.text:
creation fall into that category. We cannot
test, observe or repeat them.”

931.text:
So here we go with the “historical” and
“observable” science bullshit that I promised

935.text:
your paymaster I’d eventually deal with.
I’ll begin by saying that this distinction

940.text:
is a completely arbitrary one used to describe
the differences between disciplines that are

944.text:
aimed at understanding events that occurred
in the past versus ones that seek to explain

948.text:
events that we can observe occurring in the
present. It is just as arbitrary as those

952.text:
between, say, physical and biological sciences,
or between quantum and classical physics,

957.text:
or between plant and animal biology.
These dichotomies are the result of human

962.text:
language and our brains’ propensities for
categorization. They provide useful distinctions

967.text:
for the purposes of communication, but no
serious scientist believes that any of them,

971.text:
yours included, represents fundamental divides
in the scientific enterprise. Because while

976.text:
different fields may indeed require different
experimental or observational approaches or

980.text:
methodologies and different conceptual paradigms,
they all follow the same systematic approach

985.text:
towards investigating the nature of the physical
world.

989.text:
The only reason mentally and emotionally stunted
oafs like you make this distinction isn’t

994.text:
because of a demarcation of the past and present
that somehow presents an insurmountable epistemic

999.text:
barrier, but rather and solely because what
we’ve learned about the past runs contrary

1003.text:
to the primitive fables you desperately wish
to cling to for succor. I think we can safely

1008.text:
posit this as being true, because I don’t
recall ever hearing any creationist numbnut

1012.text:
opining on the virtues of observational over
futuristic science while simultaneously warning

1018.text:
us of the evils of listening to the Weather
Channel or of trusting NASA with when and

1022.text:
where to see the next solar eclipse.
Furthermore, despite your assertions to the

1026.text:
contrary, it seems that the global mining
industry disagrees with your assessment and

1030.text:
in fact spends hundreds of millions of dollars
on geologists to locate new reserves of minerals

1035.text:
and fossil fuels based on their knowledge
of “historical science” and an ancient

1039.text:
Earth, and then billions of dollars more on
exploration based on their advice.

1044.text:
I find it very amusing therefore, that the
very sciences and discoveries that you have

1049.text:
the temerity to deny, are the same ones that
allows you to gas-up your car so you can drive

1054.text:
your useless arse to church on a Sunday and
talk to the ceiling. Once you and your fellow

1059.text:
simpletons use your “creation science”
come up with an alternative way to find these

1063.text:
reserves that amount to more than sticking
a pin in a map and praying to Jesus for a

1068.text:
bit of luck, and once you get Exxon to start
paying you to do it, then maybe I’ll have

1073.text:
some time to actually listen to you. In the
meantime I’ll like to ask you to kindly

1077.text:
stop crapping so enthusiastically on the work
and achievements of those who make your worthless

1082.text:
lives better and just shut the fuck up.
“Yes, we do see fossils and distant stars.

1091.text:
But their history of how they got here really
depends on our world view. Do we start with

1095.text:
Man’s ideas about the past, who wasn’t

1099.text:
of Earth history? Or do we start with the
bible, the written revelation of the eye-witness

1103.text:
account of the eternal God who created it
all? Rather than being inconsistent, as Bill

Nye states, er… observational science confirms

1115.text:
Of course you didn’t have the courtesy to
support that bold assertion by spending any

1119.text:
time explaining how observational science
confirms this “literal history”, so in

1124.text:
the absence of such revelations I’m going
to assume that your referring to the same

1128.text:
derisible bullshit that creationists have
been trying to pass off as Shinola for decades.

1133.text:
This bullshit, of course, includes that unsubstantiated
assertion that your book is an “eye witness

1138.text:
account” and not an allegory, which I might
remind you the vast majority of Christians

1142.text:
find just as pungent as I do. So as far as
I’m concerned, you can take that assertion

1147.text:
and insert it as vigorously possible so it

1153.text:
As for your ideas on perspective, perhaps
this is a good time for me to point out yet

1158.text:
again that just four hundred years ago pretty
much everyone started off with your world

1162.text:
view. Fortunately for our species, though,

1167.text:
religious enquirers didn’t ignore the evidence

1171.text:
notions and instead followed that evidence

1177.text:
has slipped your notice, perhaps because you
were too busy reading your bible during your

1181.text:
graduate and undergraduate studies rather
than the text books that might have actually

1185.text:
taught you something new and turned you into
a productive human being instead of an organic

1190.text:
device for wasting oxygen.
Thus, for your information, these “man’s

1195.text:
ideas about the past” you refer to all began
with your world view. It’s just that intelligent

1200.text:
people who were capable of objectively viewing
the evidence and coming to rational and reasoned

1205.text:
conclusions realized that it was fundamentally

1210.text:
to go on living in the past like sniveling
children clinging to the skirts of the beliefs

1214.text:
that they find most comforting rather standing
up like adults and following them into the

1220.text:
light.
“The second point that Bill makes in his

1225.text:
video is that evolution is fundamental…
er… to all life science. That life science

1230.text:
can’t be practiced… er… without it.
This is certainly not the case.”

1236.text:
Well, as much as it pains me to do so, Dee,
I shall have to agree with the words you said

1241.text:
here but not with the spirit behind them,
which I will now proceed to roll up and slowly

1246.text:
insert back where it belongs. It is indeed
true that isolated aspects of biological sciences

1252.text:
can be practiced without resorting to evolutionary
theory, but only to a limited degree. More

1258.text:
specifically, those aspects are involved with
describing and elucidating the mechanisms

1262.text:
of life. We don’t need evolutionary theory
to sequence a genome, to determine a sequence

1267.text:
of events in a signal transduction cascade
or to elucidate the molecular transformations

1272.text:
occurring during enzymatic catalysis.
But what you missed out, is that without the

1277.text:
theory of evolution we simply can’t explain
why we see what we do. Without evolution we

1282.text:
can’t explain the patterns of striking similarities
and differences between the genomes of different

1287.text:
organisms. Without evolution we can’t explain
why some pathways are redundant or why components

1292.text:
can be functionally substituted between diverse
organisms. And without evolution we can’t

1298.text:
explain why enzyme homologs from different
species possess very different activities.

1303.text:
So while you certainly can describe biological
systems in a vacuum, the principle that Mr.

1307.text:
Nye was articulating is that you cannot develop
a deep and unifying explanation for those

1312.text:
observations outside of the framework of evolutionary
theory. I can see why this doesn’t occur

1317.text:
to you because you appear to have been pretty
much and anatomist and histologist before

1321.text:
you sold your soul to the Antipodean Devil,
and so probably fell into that shrinking class

1325.text:
of anachronistic stamp collectors who were
content to simply catalog natural phenomena

1330.text:
rather than seeking to explain them. This
inability to transition into doing true exploratory

1335.text:
research may explain why your career fizzled
out so pitifully, and also why you seem to

1340.text:
be unable to comprehend the bigger picture
Mr. Nye was alluding to.

1345.text:
“The evolutionist, Adam Wilkins, publishing
in Bioessays, volume 22, er… number 12,

1353.text:
says as follows…”
I stopped it here to quickly note my amusement

1358.text:
at you referring to Dr. Wilkins as an “evolutionist”.
I’m sure that you did to give the dishonest

1363.text:
impression that biologists are divided into
two camps on this issue, when I’m sure you’re

1368.text:
aware that something like 99.8% of biologists
and earth scientists accept evolutionary theory

1373.text:
as being broadly correct, so this little trick
hardly reflect well on you. In fact, the only

1379.text:
impression you left on me is that of a lying,
deceptive, filthy and probably flatulent toad.

1386.text:
So with that said let’s move on and see
what inevitable act of outrageous mendacity

1391.text:
I’m sure you’re preparing to perpetrate
on Dr. Wilkins.

1396.text:
“While the great majority biologists would
probably agree with Theodosius Dobzhansky,

1403.text:
that ‘nothing in biology makes sense without
evolution. Y et he said, most can conduct

1409.text:
their work quite happily without particular
reference to evolutionary ideas. He concluded

1415.text:
that evolution would appear to be an indispensable
unifying idea and, at the same time, a highly

1423.text:
superfluous one.”
Unfortunately Dee, what you neglected to do

1428.text:
was to read the very next paragraph, which
I will now do for you: “Yet, the marginality

1433.text:
of evolutionary biology may be changing. More
and more issues in biology, from diverse questions

1439.text:
about human nature to the vulnerability of
ecosystems, are increasingly seen as reflecting

1444.text:
evolutionary events.”
Furthermore you also mysteriously didn’t

1448.text:
mention that that whole issue of Bioessays
was dedicated to articles about these events

1453.text:
and, I quote: “the ways they shape the properties
of living things, from bacteria to humans.”

1459.text:
So there’s not much more to say, is there
